( Fig. 8 ). 4 Discussion Transcriptomics and metabolomics were combined in our research to understand the mechanism of nano-emulsion as an exogenous elicitor confers resistance to citrus against P. digitatum infection. These results will give us more information from molecular level to understand the mechanism of transcriptome reprogramming, primary and secondary metabolism of citrus under biotic stress. In this research, eugenol, cinnamaldehyde and carvacrol were encapsulated in nano-emulsion system to deliver elicitor to confer resistance against P. digitatum infection of ‘Newhall’ navel orange. The results indicated that the DEGs and DAMs were significantly enriched in pentose and glucuronate interconversions; phenylpropanoid biosynthesis; tryptophan metabolism; flavonoid biosynthesis; stilbenoid, diarylheptanoid and gingerol biosynthesis, indicating that primary and secondary metabolites induced by nano-emulsion involved in enhanced disease resistance in citrus fruit. 4.1 Defense enzyme activity and antifungal metabolites contributed to disease resistance Previous researches have demonstrated that ROS level is closely associated with plant defense performance, excessive ROS might cause oxidative stress leading to membrane damage. Plants have enzymatic antioxidant and non-enzymatic antioxidant system can scavenge excess ROS. In enzymatic antioxidant system, SOD, CAT, and APX play decisive role as ROS scavenger ( Vuleta et al., 2016 ). The antioxidant enzymes activities can be activated by H 2 O 2 ( Joradol et al., 2019 ). Whereas, lipid peroxidation can be happened when excessive H 2 O 2 produced, the enzyme of CAT and POD as ROS scavenger can work synergistically to scavenge excess H 2 O 2 to prevent the cell from damage in plant. Our study revealed that the enhanced CAT, POD and SOD activity in inoculation citrus fruit by nano-emulsion elicitation compare with control. Similar research indicated that cinnamaldehyde can effectively confer resistance to citrus by increasing the defense-related enzyme activities and secondary metabolites ( Duan et al., 2021 ). Phenylpropanoid pathway can produce antifungal metabolites such as phenols and flavonoids and the enzyme PAL, 4CL, C4H and CAD are crucial enzyme in this pathway ( Yadav et al., 2020 ). Our results also observed that higher enzyme activities of PAL, C4H, CAD and 4CL along with total higher flavonoid, total phenolic and lignin contents in nano-emulsion treated fruit compare with control in whole inoculation period. In our study, the significantly accumulated phenolic acid from phenylpropanoid biosynthesis pathway including caffeic acid, coniferyl alcohol, coniferaldehyde caffeoylquinic acid after nano-emulsion treatment compare with control. Correspondingly, three gene encoding shikimate O-hydroxycinnamoyltransferase, two genes encoding caffeoyl-CoA O-methyltransferase, one gene encoding cinnamyl-alcohol dehydrogenase, one gene encoding caffeic acid 3-O-methyltransferase, eleven gene encoding peroxidase were upregulated, indicating that the enhanced resistance by nanoemlsion treatment. The lignin and flavonoid contents also increased by elicitor compare with control during whole inoculation period, gene expression results showed that there were five genes up-regulated from 1.024 to 2.546-fold in flavonoid biosynthesis; stilbenoid, diarylheptanoid and gingerol biosynthesis pathway in our study. 4.2 Amino acids metabolism contributed to disease resistance Amino acids are the main components of protein biosynthesis. They participate in plant signal transduction and stress response. In addition, they also involved in multiple biosynthesis pathways ( Hildebrandt et al., 2015 ). In this study, the amino acids of L -norleucine, L -methionine, L -phenylalanine, aspartic acid, glycine, L -tyrosine, lysine, L -tryptophan, L -glutamic acid, L -Valine accumulated significantly after nano-emulsion treatment compare with control in inoculated fruit, indicating that those amino acids were accumulated by elicitor. Tryptophan metabolism pathway, glycine, serine and threonine pathway as a precursor for generating secondary metabolites leading to defense when plant under adverse conditions ( Tunsagool et al., 2019 ). According to KEGG enrichment of DEGs of RNA-seq data, in tryptophan metabolism pathway, one gene encoding acetylserotonin O-methyltransferase, one gene encoding indole-3-pyruvate monooxygenase were upregulated, five genes encoding acetylserotonin O-methyltransferase were downregulated compare with control. All these results indicated that DEGs take part in this pathway to regulate tryptophan metabolism which play important role in P. digitatum resistance. 4.3 Organic acids metabolism contributed to disease resistance Previous Research indicated that genes involved in plants growth and development, senescence, oxidative stress, cytosolic pH, ROS production signal transduction could be modulated by GABA to enhance stress tolerance ( Khan et al., 2021 ). In our research, the GABA accumulated significantly in nano-emulsion elicited fruit compare with control sample, indicating that GABA confer resistance to citrus fruit against P. digitatum infection. Organic acids are the intermediate products of TCA cycle and the carbon provider of metabolite biosynthesis ( Mhlongo et al., 2020 ). In our research, D -malic acid and α-ketoglutarate were significantly accumulated compare with control, indicating that the nano-emulsion affected the TCA cycle of inoculated fruit. 4.4 Sugars metabolism contributed to disease resistance Soluble sugar can provide energy and substances for plant defense response, and interact with hormone signal network in plant immune system to coordinate plant immune response ( Breia et al., 2021 ; Durán-Soria et al., 2020 ). In our study, there were three soluble sugars (DL-Xylose, D -Ribose, D -Arabinose) significantly accumulated by nano-emulsion treatment compare with control. The results indicated that the nano-emulsion as an elicitor can stimulate the accumulation of soluble sugars in inoculated citrus to enhance fruit defence capability. 4.5 Host pH modifications contributed to disease resistance P. digitatum is a necrotrophic fungus which can secrete pectinases to invade citrus peel that leading to fruit maceration ( Vilanova et al., 2018 ). There are four enzymes polygalacturonases (PGs), pectate and pectin lyases (PLs), rhamnogalacturonases and rhamnogalacturonase lyases to degrade the pectin backbone during infection process ( Ramoni and Seiboth, 2016 ). PGs can hydrolyse the polygalacturonic acid chain across the oxygen bridge ( Jayani et al., 2005 ), so the galacturonic acid accumulation in infection site could regarded as a biomarker of pectin degradation caused by PGs activity. In our study, the content of galacturonic acid of nano-emulsion treatment fruit was significantly lower compare with the control samples, and four gene encoding polygalacturonases, two gene encoding pectin lyases were down-regulated, indicating that nano-emulsion treatment disrupt the P. digitatum to secrete PG and PLs to degrade pectin of citrus fruit, thus enhance the citrus resistance to P. digitatum infection. 4.6 Immunity system contributed to disease resistance There are two surveillance systems in plant, pathogen-associated molecular patterns triggered immunity (PTI) and effector-triggered immunity (ETI), which to detect pathogen secreted molecules early, respond effectively and provide robust resistant pathogen infection ( Ngou et al., 2021 ). Pathogenic molecules were detected by plant cellular receptors PRRs, WAKs, and NLRs, respectively ( Andersen et al., 2018 ). These receptors promote plant recognize the pathogen early and successfully, prevent and delay the pathogen exceeding the infection site. Our results showing the genes (LOC102611904, LOC102624685, LOC102607213, LOC102617092) encoding leucine-rich repeat receptor-like protein kinase; gene (LOC102611612; LOC102623834) encoding leucine-rich repeat receptor-like serine/threonine-protein kinase; gene (LOC107178380, LOC102607278, LOC102609131) encoding G-type lectin S-receptor-like serine/threonine-protein kinase; gene (LOC112497319, LOC102612879) encoding L -type lectin-domain containing receptor kinase VII were upregulated compare with control, which illuminated that nano-emulsion stimulate citrus fruits employ its cellular receptors for the early detection and resistance against of P. digitatum infection. 4.7 Phytohormones contributed to disease resistance Phytohormones as chemical messenger has important role to adjust plant growth, development and defence. Among different hormones in plant, jasmonic acid deemed as stress response hormones. ( Ghorbel and Brinib, 2021 ). Previous report demonstrated in Melampsora larici-populina –poplar interaction, jasmonic acid related genes expression was up-regulated to cope with the biotic stress ( Chen et al., 2021 ). In this research, RNA-seq results indicated that gene (LOC102616825) encoding jasmonate ZIM domain-containing protein and gene (LOC102607443) encoding transcription factor MYC2 up-regulated by 1.00 and 1.22-fold respectively. In addition, genes (LOC102607187) related to AUX/IAA also up-regulated 1.76-fold compare with control, indicating that these hormone signal transduction act synergistically and play important role in nano-emulsion stimulated defence resistance against P. digitatum infection. 4.8 Pathogenesis-related proteins contributed to disease resistance Chitinases is as typical pathogenesis-related proteins, which can hydrolyse and degrade chitin when fungi infect plant or fruit ( Van Loon et al., 2006 ). In previous plant–pathogen interactions, the results indicated that induced higher chitinases activity leading to fungal growth inhibition ( Lucas-Bautista et al., 2020 ). Most often, chitinases act as endochitinases or exochitinases. According to our RNA-seq results, which showed that gene (LOC102623680) encoding basic endochitinase, gene (LOC102628916) encoding chitinase-like protein1, gene (LOC102606732) encoding chitinase10, gene (LOC102628172) encoding endochitinase-like, gene (LOC102608623) encoding endochitinase EP3 were up-regulated compare with control. These results demonstrated that gene encoding chitinase was induced and highly expressed after exogenous stimulation. Corresponding with the changes in gene expression level, our results also showed that nano-emulsion stimulate the higher chitinases activity compare with control. Previous results also reported higher chitinases activity by elicitor ( Wang et al., 2021 ). 5 Conclusions This work comprehensively investigated a combination of cinnamaldehyde, carvacrol and eugenol were encapsulated in a stable nano-emulsion as an elicitor to induce disease resistance against P. digitatum in ‘Newhall’ navel orange through transcriptomic and metabolomic profiling. A total of 653 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified between control (48 hpi) and nano-emulsion treatment (48 hpi) of fruit transcriptome, including 444 up-regulated and 209 downregulated genes. Genes encoding caffeoyl-shikimate O-hydroxycinnamoyltransferase (HCT), caffeoyl-CoA O-methyltransferase (CCoAOMT), caffeic acid 3-O-methyltransferase / acetylserotonin O-methyltransferase (COMT), cinnamyl-alcohol dehydrogenase (CAD) and peroxidase (POD) were differentially expressed by nano-emulsion treatment. In addition, 175 differential accumulated metabolites between the control and the nano-emulsion-treated fruit at 48 hpi also were identified, the different accumulated metabolites from phenylpropanoid biosynthesis pathway related with disease resistance including L -phenylalanine, caffeic acid, caffeoyl quinic acid, coniferyl alcohol, coniferaldehyde. The integrated transcriptomic and metabolomic profiling indicated that the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) and the differentially accumulated metabolites (DAMs) were mainly involved in phenylpropanoid biosynthesis pathway. Besides, the nano-emulsion significantly induced accumulation of important amino acids, soluble sugars, organic acids, lipids, sugar and alcohols. The results also indicated that the antioxidant enzyme activity, PR related enzyme and secondary metabolites biosynthesis related enzyme activity were increased by nano-emulsion treatment, including peroxidase (POD), catalase (CAT), superoxide dismutase (SOD), ascorbate peroxidase (APX), β-1,3-glucanase (GLU), chitinase (CHI), phenylalanine ammonia lyase (PAL), cinnamic acid-4-hydroxylase (C4H), 4-coumaric acid: coenzyme A ligase (4CL) and cinnamyl alcohol dehydrogenase (CAD). The flavonoids, total phenolic, and lignin contents were higher and fruit firmness was enhanced in nano-emulsion treated fruit. The MDA and H 2 O 2 content were lower in the nano-emulsion treated fruit. All these results indicated that essential oil nano-emulsion as an antifungal delivery system to induce resistance against P. digitatum infection of ‘Newhall’ navel orange. Next, we aim to further verify the function of differential expressed genes and activation function of transcription factors on downstream genes. Considering the natural nontoxic attributes of cinnamaldehyde, carvacrol and eugenol, application of essential oil nano-emulsion could overcome essential oil’s drawback and confer resistance against pathogen infection of fruit. Whereas, further research will be required to study the nano-emulsion impacts on texture, flavor properties of fruit in field application. We believe that our results will give theoretical foundation for the exploitation and application of plant extract essential oil encapsulated in nano-emulsion as a biological fungicide.
